question: In winter, road signs can become covered by snow. What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: The 'stop' sign is the only road sign that's octagonal. This is so that it can be recognised and obeyed even if it's obscured (for example, by snow).

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: When you see this sign, look out for any direction signs and judge whether you need to signal your intentions. Do this in good time so that other road users approaching the roundabout know what you're planning to do.

question: What's the reason for the hatched area along the centre of this road?

options.option: It separates traffic flowing in opposite directions
It marks an area to be used by overtaking motorcyclists
It's a temporary marking to warn of the roadworks
It separates the two sides of the dual carriageway

correct_answer: It separates traffic flowing in opposite directions

explanation.text: Areas of 'hatched markings' such as these separate traffic streams that could be a danger to each other. They're often seen on bends or where the road becomes narrow. If the area is bordered by a solid white line, you mustn't enter it except in an emergency.

question: You're at a junction controlled by traffic lights. When should you wait at a green light?

options.option: When pedestrians are waiting to cross
When your exit from the junction is blocked
When you think the lights may be about to change
When you intend to turn right

correct_answer: When your exit from the junction is blocked

explanation.text: As you approach the traffic lights, look into the road you wish to take. Only proceed if your exit road is clear. If the road is blocked, hold back, even if you have to wait for the next green signal.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: You'll need to slow down. At hump bridges, your view ahead will be restricted and the road will often be narrow. If the bridge is very steep, sound your horn to warn others of your approach. Going over the bridge too fast is highly dangerous to other road users and could even cause your wheels to leave the road, with a resulting loss of control.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: Through traffic to use left lane

explanation.text: You should change lanes as directed by the sign. Here, the right-hand lane is closed but the left-hand and centre lanes are available. Merging in turn is recommended when it's safe and traffic is going slowly; for example, at roadworks or a road traffic incident. When vehicles are travelling at speed, this isn't advisable and you should move into the appropriate lane in good time.

question: Where would you find green reflective studs on a motorway?

options.option: Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
Between the carriageway and the central reservation

explanation.text: Knowing the colours of the reflective studs on the road will help you judge your position, especially at night, in foggy conditions or when visibility is poor.

question: Where would you see this road marking?

explanation.text: Because the road has a dark colour, changes in level aren't easily seen. White triangles painted on the road surface give you an indication of where there are road humps.

question: Where would you find these road markings?

explanation.text: These markings show the direction in which the traffic should go at a mini-roundabout.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: Level crossing with gate or barrier
Level crossing without gate or barrier

correct_answer: Level crossing with gate or barrier

explanation.text: Some crossings have gates but no attendant or signals. You should stop, look both ways, listen and make sure that no train is approaching. If there's a telephone, contact the signal operator to make sure it's safe to cross.

question: Where would you find these flashing red light signals?

explanation.text: These signals are found at level crossings, swing or lifting bridges, some airfields and emergency access sites. The flashing red lights mean stop whether or not the way seems to be clear.

question: What does this signal mean?

options.option: Both trams and cars must stop
Both trams and cars can continue

explanation.text: The white light shows that trams must stop. The green light shows that other vehicles can go if the way is clear. Trams are being introduced into more cities, so you're likely to come across them and you should learn which signs apply to them.

question: Which type of vehicle does this sign apply to?

explanation.text: The triangular shapes above and below the dimensions indicate a height restriction that applies to the road ahead.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: A sign will indicate which types of vehicles are prohibited from certain roads. Make sure that you know which signs apply to the vehicle you're using.

question: What should you be aware of if you've just passed this sign?

options.option: You can't stop on this road
Only one lane is in use
All traffic is going one way

correct_answer: All traffic is going one way

explanation.text: In a one-way system, traffic may pass you on either side. Always be aware of all traffic signs and understand their meaning. Look well ahead and react to them in good time.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Where you see this sign, the 20 mph restriction ends and a 30 mph restriction starts. Check all around for possible hazards and only increase your speed if it's safe to do so.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Take extra care when you encounter trams. Look out for road markings and signs that alert you to them. Modern trams are very quiet and you may not hear them approaching.

question: Which is the sign for a ring road?

explanation.text: Ring roads are designed to relieve congestion in towns and city centres.

question: What shape is a 'stop' sign?

explanation.text: To make it easy to recognise, the 'stop' sign is the only sign of this shape. You must stop and take effective observation before proceeding.

question: What does this road marking mean?

explanation.text: A single broken line along the centre of the road, with long markings and short gaps, is a hazard warning line. Don't cross it unless you can see that the road is clear well ahead.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: When you leave the motorway, make sure that you check your speedometer. You may be going faster than you realise. Slow down and look for speed-limit signs.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: A warning sign with a picture of a windsock indicates that there may be strong side winds. This sign is often found on exposed roads.

question: You're driving in busy traffic. You want to pull up just after a junction on the left. When should you signal?

options.option: As you're passing or just after the junction
Just before you reach the junction
Well before you reach the junction
It would be better not to signal at all

correct_answer: As you're passing or just after the junction

explanation.text: You need to signal to let other drivers know your intentions. However, if you indicate too early, they may think you're turning left into the junction. Correct timing of the signal is very important to avoid misleading others.

question: What does this motorway sign mean?

options.option: Change to the lane on your left
Leave the motorway at the next exit
Pull up on the hard shoulder

correct_answer: Change to the lane on your left

explanation.text:
On the motorway, signs sometimes show temporary warnings due to traffic or weather conditions. They may be used to indicate
  • lane closures
  • temporary speed limits
  • weather warnings.

question: What must you do when you see this sign?

options.option: Stop only if traffic is approaching
Stop even if the road is clear
Stop only if children are waiting to cross
Stop only if a red light is showing

correct_answer: Stop even if the road is clear

explanation.text: 'Stop' signs are situated at junctions where visibility is restricted or where there's heavy traffic. They must be obeyed: you must stop. Look carefully before moving off.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: Two-way traffic crosses a one-way road

explanation.text: This sign may be at the end of a dual carriageway or a one-way street. It's there to warn you of oncoming traffic.

question: What does this sign indicate?

explanation.text: When a diversion route has been put in place, drivers are advised to follow a symbol, which may be a black triangle, square, circle or diamond shape on a yellow background.

question: Which sign means turn left ahead?

explanation.text: Blue circles tell you what you must do and this sign gives a clear instruction to turn left ahead. You should be looking out for signs at all times and know what they mean.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Avoid blocking tram routes. Trams are fixed on their route and can't manoeuvre around other vehicles or pedestrians. Modern trams travel quickly and are quiet, so you might not hear them approaching.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: Approaching traffic passes you on both sides
Turn off at the next available junction
Pass either side to get to the same destination

correct_answer: Pass either side to get to the same destination

explanation.text: These signs are often seen in one-way streets that have more than one lane. When you see this sign, use the route that's the most convenient and doesn't require a late change of direction.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Obey the 'give way' signs. Trams are unable to steer around you if you misjudge when it's safe to enter the junction.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: This sign is found where a shallow stream crosses the road. Heavy rainfall could increase the flow of water. If the water looks too deep or the stream has spread over a large distance, stop and find another route.

question: A police car is following you. What should you do if the police officer flashes the headlights and points to the left?

options.option: Turn left at the next junction

explanation.text: You must pull up on the left as soon as it’s safe to do so and switch off your engine.

question: What does this line across the road at the entrance to a roundabout mean?

options.option: Give way to traffic from the right
Traffic from the left has right of way

correct_answer: Give way to traffic from the right

explanation.text: Slow down as you approach the roundabout and check for traffic from the right. If you need to stop and give way, stay behind the broken line until it's safe to emerge onto the roundabout.

question: You're in the left-hand lane at traffic lights, waiting to turn left. Which signal means you must wait?

explanation.text: At some junctions, there may be separate signals for different lanes. These are called 'filter' lights. They're designed to help traffic flow at major junctions. Make sure that you're in the correct lane and proceed if the way is clear and the green light shows for your lane.

question: What's the purpose of triangular shaped signs?

explanation.text: Triangular signs warn you of hazards ahead. Make sure you look at each sign that you pass on the road, so that you don't miss any vital instructions or information.

question: What messages are given by circular traffic signs that have a blue background?

options.option: They give temporary directions during a diversion
They give directions to car parks

explanation.text: Signs with blue circles generally give mandatory instruction. These are often found in urban areas and include signs for mini-roundabouts and directional arrows.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: When approaching a tunnel, switch on your dipped headlights. Be aware that your eyes might need to adjust to the sudden darkness. You may need to reduce your speed.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: No waiting for buses and cycles

explanation.text: Buses and cycles can travel in this lane. In this example, they'll flow in the same direction as other traffic. If it's busy, they may be passing you on the left, so watch out for them. Times on the sign will show the lane's hours of operation; if no times are shown, or there's no sign at all, this means the lane is in operation 24 hours a day. In some areas, other vehicles, such as taxis and motorcycles, are allowed to use bus lanes. The sign will show if this is the case.

question: What does this traffic sign mean?

explanation.text: This sign is there to alert you to the likelihood of danger ahead. It may be accompanied by a plate indicating the type of hazard. Be ready to reduce your speed and take avoiding action.

question: What does this motorway sign mean?

explanation.text: Look out for signs above your lane or on the central reservation. These will give you important information or warnings about the road ahead. To allow for the high speed of motorway traffic, these signs may light up some distance from any hazard. Don't ignore the signs just because the road looks clear to you.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: The priority through the junction is shown by the broader line. You need to be aware of the hazard posed by traffic crossing or pulling out onto a major road.

question: You're about to overtake. What should you do when you see this sign?

options.option: Overtake the other driver as quickly as possible
Move to the right to get a better view
Switch your headlights on before overtaking
Hold back until you can see clearly ahead

correct_answer: Hold back until you can see clearly ahead

explanation.text:
You won't be able to see any hazards that might be hidden in the dip. As well as oncoming traffic, the dip may conceal
  • cyclists
  • horse riders
  • parked vehicles
  • pedestrians
in the road.

question: You're in a tunnel and you see this sign. What does it mean?

options.option: Direction to an emergency pedestrian exit
Beware of pedestrians: no footpath ahead

correct_answer: Direction to an emergency pedestrian exit

explanation.text: If you have to leave your vehicle and get out of a tunnel by an emergency exit, do so as quickly as you can. Follow the signs directing you to the nearest exit point. If there are several people using the exit, don't panic but try to leave in a calm and orderly manner.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: 'No entry' signs are used in places such as one-way streets to prevent vehicles driving against the traffic. To ignore one would be dangerous, both for yourself and for other road users, as well as being against the law.

question: Where can you find reflective amber studs on a motorway?

options.option: Separating the slip road from the motorway
On the left-hand edge of the road
On the right-hand edge of the road

correct_answer: On the right-hand edge of the road

explanation.text: At night or in poor visibility, reflective studs on the road help you to judge your position on the carriageway.

question: When may you cross a double solid white line in the middle of the road?

options.option: To pass traffic that's queuing back at a junction
To pass a car signalling to turn left ahead
To pass a road maintenance vehicle travelling at 10 mph or less
To pass a vehicle that's towing a trailer

correct_answer: To pass a road maintenance vehicle travelling at 10 mph or less

explanation.text: You may cross the solid white line to pass a stationary vehicle or to pass a pedal cycle, horse or road maintenance vehicle if it's travelling at 10 mph or less. You may also cross the solid white line to enter a side road or access a property.

question: Which sign means there's a double bend ahead?

explanation.text: Triangular signs give you a warning of hazards ahead. They're there to give you time to prepare for the hazard; for example, by adjusting your speed.

question: What shape are traffic signs giving orders?

explanation.text: Road signs in the shape of a circle give orders. Those with a red circle are mostly prohibitive. The 'stop' sign is octagonal to give it greater prominence. Signs giving orders must always be obeyed.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Look well ahead and be ready to stop for any pedestrians crossing, or about to cross, the road. Also check the pavements for anyone who looks like they might step or run into the road.

question: When may you sound your vehicle's horn?

options.option: To give you right of way
To warn others of your presence
To make slower drivers move over

correct_answer: To warn others of your presence

explanation.text: Never sound your vehicle's horn aggressively. You mustn't sound it in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am, or when you're stationary, unless another road user poses a danger. Don't scare animals by sounding your horn.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: This sign tells you to beware of trams. If you don't usually drive in a town where there are trams, remember to look out for them at junctions and look for tram rails, signs and signals.

question: Which arm signal tells you that the car you're following is going to pull up?

explanation.text: There may be occasions when drivers need to give an arm signal to confirm their intentions. This could include in bright sunshine, at a complex road layout, when stopping at a pedestrian crossing or when turning right just after passing a parked vehicle. You should understand what each arm signal means. If you give arm signals, make them clear, correct and decisive.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: You must comply with all traffic signs and be especially aware of those signs that apply specifically to the type of vehicle you're using.

question: What should you do when you see this sign as you travel along a motorway?

options.option: Leave the motorway at the next exit

correct_answer: Leave the motorway at the next exit

explanation.text: You'll see this sign if the motorway is closed ahead. Pull into the left-hand lane as soon as it's safe to do so. Don't wait until the last moment before you move across, because the lane may be busy and you'll have to rely on another driver making room for you.

question: What do the long white lines along the centre of the road mean?

explanation.text: The centre of the road is usually marked by a broken white line, with lines that are shorter than the gaps. When the lines become longer than the gaps, this is a hazard warning line. Look well ahead for these, especially when you're planning to overtake or turn off.

question: At traffic lights, what does it mean when the amber light shows on its own?

options.option: Go if the way is clear
Go if no pedestrians are crossing

explanation.text: When the amber light is showing on its own, the red light will follow next. The amber light means stop, unless you've already crossed the stop line or you're so close to it that stopping may cause a collision.

question: When may you use hazard warning lights while you're driving?

options.option: Instead of sounding the horn in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am
On a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway, to warn of a hazard ahead
On rural routes, after a sign warning of animals
On the approach to toucan crossings, where cyclists are waiting to cross

correct_answer: On a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway, to warn of a hazard ahead

explanation.text: When there’s queuing traffic ahead and you have to slow down or even stop, briefly showing your hazard warning lights will help alert the traffic behind to the hazard.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: This is the sign for a clearway. Clearways are stretches of road where you aren't allowed to stop unless it's an emergency. Stopping where these restrictions apply may be dangerous and is likely to cause an obstruction. Restrictions might apply for several miles and this may be indicated on the sign.

question: Which sign informs you that you're coming to a 'no through road'?

explanation.text: This sign is found at the entrance to a road that can only be used for access.

question: Where would you see a contraflow bus lane?

explanation.text: The traffic permitted to use a contraflow lane travels in the opposite direction to traffic in the other lanes on the road.

question: What do these zigzag white lines mean?

options.option: Parking allowed only for a short time

explanation.text: The approach to, and exit from, a pedestrian crossing is marked with zigzag lines. You mustn't park on them or overtake the leading vehicle when approaching the crossing. Parking here would block the view for pedestrians and approaching traffic.

question: Which sign means that the national speed limit applies?

explanation.text: You should know the speed limit for the road on which you're travelling and for your vehicle. The different speed limits are shown in The Highway Code.

question: Which of these signs warns you of a zebra crossing?

explanation.text: Look well ahead and check the pavements and surrounding areas for pedestrians. Look for anyone walking towards the crossing. Check your mirrors for traffic behind, in case you have to slow down or stop.

question: What does this traffic sign mean?

explanation.text:
Priority signs are normally shown where the road is narrow and there isn't enough room for two vehicles to pass. Examples are narrow bridges, roadworks and where there's a width restriction.
Make sure you know who has priority; don't force your way through. Show courtesy and consideration to other road users.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Where there's a cycle route ahead, a sign will show a bicycle in a red warning triangle. Watch out for children on bicycles and cyclists rejoining the main road.

question: What does '25' mean on this motorway sign?

options.option: The distance to the nearest town
The route number of the road
The number of the next junction
The speed limit on the slip road

correct_answer: The number of the next junction

explanation.text: Before you set out on your journey, use a road map to plan your route. When you see an advance warning of your junction, make sure you get into the correct lane in plenty of time. Last-minute harsh braking and cutting across lanes at speed is extremely hazardous.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: No parking for buses or coaches
Direction to bus and coach park
Parking area for cars and coaches

explanation.text:
To ease the congestion in town centres, some cities and towns provide park-and-ride schemes. These allow you to park in a designated area and ride by bus into the centre.
Park-and-ride schemes are usually cheaper and easier than car parking in the town centre.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Even though you've left the restricted area, make sure that you park where you won't endanger other road users or cause an obstruction.

question: Your vehicle is stationary. When may you use its horn?

options.option: When another road user poses a danger
When the road is blocked by queuing traffic
When signalling that you've just arrived

correct_answer: When another road user poses a danger

explanation.text: When your vehicle is stationary, only sound the horn if you think there's a risk of danger from another road user. Don't use it just to attract someone's attention. This causes unnecessary noise and could be misleading.

question: What should you do when you're approaching traffic lights that have red and amber showing together?

options.option: Pass the lights if the road is clear
Take care because there's a fault with the lights
Stop because the lights are changing to red

explanation.text: Be aware that other traffic might still be clearing the junction as you approach. A green light means you may go on, but only if the way is clear.

question: Which sign means that pedestrians may be walking along the road?

explanation.text: When you pass pedestrians in the road, leave plenty of room. You might have to use the right-hand side of the road, so look well ahead, as well as in your mirrors, before pulling out. Take great care if a bend in the road obscures your view ahead.

question: You're approaching a junction where the traffic lights aren't working. What should you do when a police officer gives this signal?

explanation.text: When a police officer or traffic warden is directing traffic, you must obey them. They'll use the arm signals shown in The Highway Code. Learn what these signals mean and obey them.

question: Which sign means 'no entry'?

explanation.text: Look for and obey traffic signs. Disobeying or not seeing a sign could be dangerous. It may also be an offence for which you could be prosecuted.

question: What does this sign mean?

options.option: No through road on the left
No entry for traffic turning left

correct_answer: No through road on the left

explanation.text: This sign shows you that you can't get through to another route by turning left at the junction ahead.

question: Which sign shows that you're entering a one-way system?

explanation.text: If the road has two lanes, you can use either lane and overtake on either side. Use the lane that's more convenient for your destination unless signs or road markings indicate otherwise.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: You won't be able to find a through route to another road. Use this road only for access.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: Temporary restrictions on motorways are shown on signs that have flashing amber lights. At the end of the restriction, you'll see this sign without any flashing lights.

question: You're on a motorway. What should you do if there's a red cross showing on the signs above your lane only?

options.option: Continue in that lane and look for further information
Stop and wait for an instruction to proceed

explanation.text: A red cross above your lane shows that your lane is closed. You should move into another lane as soon as you can do so safely.

question: How should the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway be used?

explanation.text: You should stay in the left-hand lane of a motorway unless you're overtaking another vehicle. The right-hand lane of a motorway is an overtaking lane; it isn't the 'fast lane'. After overtaking, move back to the left when it's safe to do so.

question: Which type of sign tells you what you must not do?

explanation.text: Signs in the shape of a circle give orders. A sign with a red circle means that you aren't allowed to do something. Study Know Your Traffic Signs to ensure that you understand what the different traffic signs mean.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: As you approach a roundabout, look well ahead and check all signs. Decide which exit you wish to take and move into the correct position as you approach the roundabout, signalling as required.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: The 'no right turn' sign may be used to warn road users that there's a 'no entry' prohibition on a road to the right ahead.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: You might see this sign where traffic lights are out of order. Proceed with caution, as nobody has priority at the junction.

question: What should you do when you see this sign at a crossroads?

explanation.text: When traffic lights are out of order, treat the junction as an unmarked crossroads. Be very careful and be prepared to stop; no-one has priority.

question: When may you stop on an urban clearway?

options.option: To set down and pick up passengers

correct_answer: To set down and pick up passengers

explanation.text: Urban clearways have their times of operation clearly signed. You may only stop to pick up or set down passengers.

question: What should you do when there's an obstruction on your side of the road?

options.option: Carry on, as you have priority

explanation.text: Take care if you have to pass an obstruction, such as a parked vehicle, on your side of the road. Give way to oncoming traffic if there isn’t enough room for you both to continue safely.

question: Which vehicle might have to take a different course from normal at a roundabout?

explanation.text:
A long vehicle may have to straddle lanes either on or approaching a roundabout so that the rear wheels don’t mount the kerb.
If you’re following a long vehicle, stay well back and give it plenty of room.

question: Where's the safest place to park your vehicle at night?

explanation.text: If you have a garage, use it. Your vehicle is less likely to be a victim of car crime if it's in a garage. Also, in winter, the windows will be kept free from ice and snow.

question: A single carriageway road has this sign. What's the maximum permitted speed for a car towing a trailer?

explanation.text: When you're towing a trailer, a reduced speed limit also applies on dual carriageways and motorways. These lower speed limits apply to vehicles pulling all sorts of trailers, including caravans and horse boxes.

question: You want to turn right at a box junction. What should you do if there's oncoming traffic?

options.option: Wait in the box junction if your exit is clear
Wait before the junction until it's clear of all traffic
Drive on; you can't turn right at a box junction
Drive slowly into the box junction when signalled by oncoming traffic

correct_answer: Wait in the box junction if your exit is clear

explanation.text: You can wait in the box junction as long as your exit is clear. At some point there'll be a gap in the oncoming traffic, or the traffic lights will change, allowing you to proceed.

question: You're looking for somewhere to safely park your vehicle. Where would you choose to park?

options.option: At or near a bus stop
Near the brow of a hill
On the approach to a level crossing

explanation.text: It may be tempting to park where you shouldn’t while you run a quick errand. Careless parking is a selfish act and could endanger other road users.

question: You're driving in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway. What should you do if you see a sign showing that the right-hand lane is closed 800 yards ahead?

options.option: Keep in that lane until you reach the queue
Wait and see which lane is moving faster
Move to the left in good time

correct_answer: Move to the left in good time

explanation.text:
Keep a lookout for traffic signs. If you’re directed to change lanes, do so in good time. Don’t
  • push your way into traffic in another lane
  • try to gain advantage by delaying changing lanes.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: The red slash through the sign indicates that the restriction has ended. In this case, the restriction was a minimum speed limit of 30 mph.

question: What's the meaning of this sign?

explanation.text: This sign doesn't tell you the speed limit in figures. You should know the speed limit for the type of road that you're on and the type of vehicle that you're driving or riding. Study your copy of The Highway Code.

question: You're going to turn left from a main road into a minor road. What should you do as you approach the junction?

options.option: Keep just left of the middle of the road
Keep in the middle of the road
Swing out to the right just before turning
Keep well to the left of the road

correct_answer: Keep well to the left of the road

explanation.text: Your road position can help other road users to anticipate your actions. Keep to the left as you approach a left turn and don't swing out into the centre of the road in order to make the turn easier. This could endanger oncoming traffic and may cause other road users to misunderstand your intentions.

question: You're driving on a road that has a cycle lane. What does it mean if the lane is marked by a broken white line?

options.option: You shouldn't drive in the lane unless it's unavoidable
There's a reduced speed limit for motor vehicles using the lane
Cyclists can travel in both directions in that lane
The lane must be used by motorcyclists in heavy traffic

correct_answer: You shouldn't drive in the lane unless it's unavoidable

explanation.text: Cycle lanes are marked with either a solid or a broken white line. If the line is solid, you should check the times of operation shown on the signs, and not drive or park in the lane during those times. If the line is broken, you shouldn't drive or park in the lane unless it's unavoidable.

question: Who is authorised to signal you to stop?

explanation.text: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

question: What's the nearest you may park to a junction?

explanation.text: Don't park within 10 metres (32 feet) of a junction (unless in an authorised parking place). This is to allow drivers emerging from, or turning into, the junction a clear view of the road they're joining. It also allows them to see hazards such as pedestrians or cyclists at the junction.

question: When may you enter a box junction?

options.option: When there are fewer than two vehicles ahead
When signalled by another road user
When your exit road is clear

correct_answer: When your exit road is clear

explanation.text: Yellow box junctions are marked on the road to prevent the road becoming blocked. Don’t enter the box unless your exit road is clear. You may wait in the box if you want to turn right and your exit road is clear but oncoming traffic or other vehicles waiting to turn right are preventing you from making the turn.

question: You're turning right at a crossroads. An oncoming driver is also turning right. What's the advantage of turning behind the oncoming vehicle?

options.option: You'll have a clearer view of any approaching traffic
You'll use less fuel because you can stay in a higher gear
You'll have more time to turn
You'll be able to turn without stopping

correct_answer: You'll have a clearer view of any approaching traffic

explanation.text: When turning right at a crossroads where oncoming traffic is also turning right, it's generally safer to turn behind the approaching vehicle. This allows you a clear view of approaching traffic and is called 'turning offside to offside'. However, some junctions, usually controlled by traffic-light filters - are marked for vehicles to turn nearside to nearside.

question: You're driving on a busy main road. What should you do if you find that you're driving in the wrong direction?

options.option: Turn into a side road on the right and reverse into the main road
Make a U-turn in the main road
Make a ‘three-point’ turn in the main road
Turn around in a side road

correct_answer: Turn around in a side road

explanation.text: Don’t turn around in a busy street or reverse from a side road into a main road. Find a quiet side road and choose a place to turn around where you won’t obstruct an entrance or exit. Look out for pedestrians and cyclists as well as other traffic.

question: What should you do if you want to overtake a tractor but aren't sure that it's safe?

options.option: Follow another vehicle as it overtakes the tractor
Sound your horn to make the tractor driver pull over
Speed past, flashing your lights at oncoming traffic
Stay behind it if you're in any doubt

correct_answer: Stay behind it if you're in any doubt

explanation.text: Following a tractor can be frustrating, but never overtake if you’re unsure whether it’s safe. Ask yourself: 'Can I see far enough down the road to ensure that I can complete the manoeuvre safely?' It's better to be delayed for a minute or two than to take a chance that may cause a collision.

question: What signal should you give when you're going straight ahead at a roundabout?

options.option: Signal left before leaving the roundabout
Signal right when you're approaching the roundabout
Signal left when you're approaching the roundabout

correct_answer: Signal left before leaving the roundabout

explanation.text: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Signal left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

question: Other than direction indicators, how can you give signals to other road users?

explanation.text: Your brake lights will give an indication to traffic behind that you're slowing down. Good anticipation will allow you time to check your mirrors before slowing.

question: You want to park and you see this sign. What should you do on the days and times shown?

options.option: Park in a bay and not pay
Park on yellow lines and pay
Park on yellow lines and not pay
Park in a bay and pay

correct_answer: Park in a bay and pay

explanation.text: Parking restrictions apply in a variety of places and situations. Make sure you know the rules and understand where and when restrictions apply. Controlled parking areas will be indicated by signs and road markings. Parking in the wrong place could cause an obstruction and danger to other traffic. It can also result in a fine.

question: Why could it be dangerous to reverse from a side road into a main road?

options.option: Your reversing lights will be hidden

explanation.text: Don’t reverse into a main road from a side road because your view will be restricted. The main road is likely to be busy and the traffic on it moving quickly.

question: When must you stop your vehicle?

options.option: If you’re involved in an incident that causes damage or injury
At a junction where there are ‘give way’ lines
At the end of a one-way street

correct_answer: If you’re involved in an incident that causes damage or injury

explanation.text:
You must stop your vehicle when signalled to do so by a
  • police, DVSA or traffic officer
  • traffic warden
  • school crossing patrol
  • red traffic light.
You must also stop if you're involved in an incident that causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property.

question: Where will you see these red and white markers?

options.option: Approaching the end of a motorway
Approaching the end of a dual carriageway

explanation.text: If there's a bend just before a level crossing, you may not be able to see the level-crossing barriers or waiting traffic. These signs give you an early warning that you may find these hazards just around the bend.

question: You're parked in a busy high street. What's the safest way to turn your vehicle around so you can drive in the opposite direction?

options.option: Turn around in a quiet side road
Drive into a side road and reverse out into the main road
Ask someone to stop the traffic

correct_answer: Turn around in a quiet side road

explanation.text: Make sure you carry out the manoeuvre without causing a hazard to other vehicles. Choose a place to turn that's safe and considers other road users.

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation.text: This sign shows that you're leaving a controlled parking zone and those restrictions no longer apply.

question: You're in a built-up area at night and the road is well lit. Why should you use dipped headlights?

options.option: So that you can see further along the road
So that you can go at a much faster speed
So that you can switch to main beam quickly
So that you can be easily seen by others

correct_answer: So that you can be easily seen by others

explanation.text: You may be difficult to see when you’re travelling at night, even on a well-lit road. If you use dipped headlights rather than sidelights, other road users should be able to see you more easily.

question: You're reversing into a side road. When would your vehicle be the greatest hazard to passing traffic?

options.option: Just before you begin to manoeuvre
After you’ve entered the side road
When the front of your vehicle swings out

correct_answer: When the front of your vehicle swings out

explanation.text: Always check in all directions before reversing. Keep a good lookout throughout the manoeuvre and remember that the front will swing out as you reverse into the side road. Act on what you see and wait if necessary.

question: You're travelling along a residential street. There are parked vehicles on the left-hand side. Why should you keep your speed down?

options.option: So that oncoming traffic can see you more clearly
You may set off car alarms
There may be delivery lorries on the street
Children may run out from between the vehicles

correct_answer: Children may run out from between the vehicles

explanation.text:
Travel slowly and carefully near parked vehicles. Beware of
  • vehicles pulling out, especially bicycles and motorcycles
  • pedestrians, especially children, who may run out from between cars
  • drivers opening their doors.

question: A cycle lane, marked by a solid white line, is in operation. What does this mean for car drivers?

options.option: They may park in the lane
They may drive in the lane at any time
They may use the lane when necessary
They mustn't drive along the lane

correct_answer: They mustn't drive along the lane

explanation.text: While it's in operation, other vehicles must not use this part of the carriageway except to pick up or set down passengers. At other times, when the lane isn't in operation, you should still be aware that there may be cyclists using the lane. Give them plenty of room as you pass and allow for their movement from side to side, especially in windy weather or on a bumpy road.

question: What must you do if you come across roadworks that have a temporary speed limit displayed?

options.option: Obey the limit, but only during rush hour
Use your own judgement; the limit is only advisory

explanation.text: Where there are extra hazards, such as at roadworks, it's often necessary to slow traffic by imposing a lower speed limit. These speed limits aren't advisory; they must be obeyed.

question: Which road users benefit from toucan crossings?

explanation.text: Toucan crossings are similar to pelican crossings but there's no flashing amber phase. Cyclists share the crossing with pedestrians and are allowed to cycle across when the green cycle symbol is shown.

question: You see these double white lines along the centre of the road. When may you park on the left?

options.option: If the line nearest to you is broken
When there are no yellow lines
To pick up or set down passengers

correct_answer: To pick up or set down passengers

explanation.text: You mustn't park or stop on a road marked with double white lines (even where one of the lines is broken) except to pick up or set down passengers.

question: You're turning right onto a dual carriageway. What should you do if the central reservation is too narrow to contain your vehicle?

options.option: Proceed to the central reservation and wait
Wait until the road is clear in both directions
Stop in the first lane so that other vehicles give way
Emerge slightly to show your intentions

correct_answer: Wait until the road is clear in both directions

explanation.text: When the central reservation is narrow, it may not be able to contain your vehicle. In this case, you should treat a dual carriageway as one road. Wait until the road is clear in both directions before emerging to turn right. If you try to treat it as two separate roads and wait in the middle, your vehicle will stick out and cause an obstruction that may lead to a collision.

question: How should you signal if you're going straight ahead at a roundabout?

options.option: Signal right on the approach and then left to leave the roundabout
Signal left after you leave the roundabout and enter the new road
Signal right on the approach to the roundabout and keep the signal on
Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you're going to take

correct_answer: Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you're going to take

explanation.text: To go straight ahead at a roundabout, you should normally approach in the left-hand lane, but check the road markings. At some roundabouts, the left lane on approach is marked ‘left turn only’, so make sure you use the correct lane to go ahead. You won't normally need to signal as you approach, but signal before you leave the roundabout, as other road users need to know your intentions.

question: When may you drive a car in this bus lane?

options.option: To get to the front of a traffic queue
You may not use it at any time

explanation.text: Some bus lanes operate only during peak hours and other vehicles may use them outside these hours. Make sure you check the sign for the hours of operation before driving in a bus lane.

question: Where should you park your vehicle at night?

explanation.text: When you're parking at night, park in a well-lit area. This can help deter criminals from targeting your vehicle.

question: When may you drive without wearing your seat belt?

options.option: When you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing
When you're moving off on a hill
When you're driving slowly in queuing traffic

correct_answer: When you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing

explanation.text: You may remove your seat belt while you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing. However, you must remember to put it back on again before you resume driving.

question: When are you allowed to park in a parking bay for disabled drivers?

options.option: When you have a Blue Badge
When you have an advanced driver certificate
When you have an adapted vehicle

correct_answer: When you have a Blue Badge

explanation.text: Don’t park in a space reserved for disabled people unless you or your passenger are a Blue Badge holder. The badge must be displayed on the dashboard or fascia panel, where it can be clearly read through the front windscreen.

question: You're looking for somewhere to park your vehicle. Neither you or your passenger are disabled. What should you do if the only free spaces are marked for disabled drivers?

options.option: Park in one of these spaces but stay with your vehicle
Use one of the spaces as long as one is kept free
Wait for a regular parking space to become free

correct_answer: Wait for a regular parking space to become free

explanation.text: It's illegal to park in a space reserved for disabled drivers unless you're permitted to do so. These spaces are provided for people with limited mobility, who may need extra space to get in and out of their vehicle.

question: What's the national speed limit on a single carriageway road for cars and motorcycles?

explanation.text: Exceeding the speed limit is dangerous and can result in you receiving penalty points on your licence. It isn't worth it. You should know the speed limit for the road that you're on by observing the road signs. Different speed limits apply if you're towing a trailer.

question: In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland what will the speed limit usually be where you can see street lights but no speed-limit signs?

explanation.text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland the presence of street lights generally indicates that there's a 30 mph speed limit, unless signs tell you otherwise.
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

question: What's the speed limit for a car towing a caravan on a dual carriageway?

explanation.text: The speed limit for cars towing caravans or trailers on dual carriageways or motorways is 60 mph. Due to the increased weight and size of the combination, you should plan further ahead. Take care in windy weather, as a strong side wind can make a caravan or large trailer unstable.

question: When may you drive over a pavement?

options.option: When the pavement is very wide
If there are no pedestrians nearby
To gain access to a property

correct_answer: To gain access to a property

explanation.text: It's illegal to drive on or over a pavement, except to gain access to a property. If you need to cross a pavement, give priority to pedestrians.

question: When may you stop on a clearway?

explanation.text: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

question: When may you stop and wait in a box junction?

options.option: When oncoming traffic prevents you from turning right
When you're in a queue of traffic turning left
When you're in a queue of traffic going ahead

correct_answer: When oncoming traffic prevents you from turning right

explanation.text: The purpose of yellow box markings is to keep junctions clear of queuing traffic. You may only wait in the marked area when you’re turning right and your exit lane is clear but you can’t complete the turn because of oncoming traffic or other traffic waiting to turn right.

question: You're looking for somewhere to park at night. When may you park on the right-hand side of the road?

options.option: When you're in a one-way street
When you have your sidelights on
When you're more than 10 metres (32 feet) from a junction

correct_answer: When you're in a one-way street

explanation.text: Red rear reflectors show up when headlights shine on them. These are useful when you're parked at night, but they'll only reflect if you park in the same direction as the traffic flow. Normally you should park on the left, but in a one-way street you may also park on the right-hand side of the road.

question: You’re waiting at a pelican crossing. What does it mean when the red light changes to flashing amber?

options.option: Give way to pedestrians on the crossing
Move off immediately without any hesitation
Wait for the green light before moving off
Get ready and go when the continuous amber light shows

correct_answer: Give way to pedestrians on the crossing

explanation.text: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

question: When would you use the right-hand lane of a two-lane dual carriageway?

options.option: When you're turning right or overtaking
When you're passing a side road on the left
When you're staying at the minimum allowed speed
When you're travelling at a constant high speed

correct_answer: When you're turning right or overtaking

explanation.text: Normally you should travel in the left-hand lane and only use the right-hand lane for overtaking or turning right. Move back into the left lane as soon as it’s safe but don’t cut in across the path of the vehicle you’ve just passed.

question: What should you do if the amber lights come on and a warning sounds while you're driving over a level crossing?

options.option: Get everyone out of the vehicle immediately
Stop and reverse back to clear the crossing
Keep going and clear the crossing
Stop immediately and use your hazard warning lights

correct_answer: Keep going and clear the crossing

explanation.text: Keep going; don’t stop on the crossing. If the warning sounds and the amber lights come on as you’re approaching the crossing, you must stop unless it's unsafe to do so. Red flashing lights together with the audible warning mean you must stop.

question: You're waiting at a level crossing. What should you do if the red warning lights continue to flash after a train has passed by?

explanation.text: At a level crossing, flashing red lights mean you must stop. If the train passes but the lights keep flashing, wait. Another train may be coming.

question: Which vehicle is most likely to take an unusual course at a roundabout?

explanation.text: Long vehicles might have to take a slightly different position when approaching the roundabout or going around it. This is to stop the rear of the vehicle cutting in and mounting the kerb.

question: What's the meaning of this sign?

explanation.text:
This sign indicates that there are waiting restrictions. It's normally accompanied by details of when the restrictions are in force.
Details of most signs in common use are shown in The Highway Code. For more comprehensive coverage, see Know Your Traffic Signs.

question: When should you use the right-hand lane of a three-lane dual carriageway?

options.option: When you're overtaking or turning right

correct_answer: When you're overtaking or turning right

explanation.text:
You should normally use the left-hand lane on any dual carriageway unless you're overtaking or turning right.
When overtaking on a dual carriageway, look for vehicles ahead that are turning right. They may be slowing or stopped. You need to see them in good time so that you can take appropriate action.

question: You're waiting at a level crossing. What must you do if a train passes but the lights keep flashing?

options.option: Edge over the stop line and look for trains

explanation.text: If the lights at a level crossing keep flashing after a train has passed, you should continue to wait, because another train might be coming. Time seems to pass slowly when you're held up in a queue. Be patient and wait until the lights stop flashing.

question: You're approaching a busy junction. What should you do when, at the last moment, you realise you're in the wrong lane?

options.option: Force your way into the lane you need
Stop until the area has cleared
Use arm signals to help you change lane

explanation.text: There are times when road markings are obscured by queuing traffic, or you're unsure which lane to use. If, at the last moment, you find you're in the wrong lane, don’t cut across or bully other drivers to let you in. Follow the lane you’re in and find somewhere safe to turn around and rejoin your route.

question: What should you do when you're unsure whether it's safe to reverse your vehicle?

explanation.text: A small child could be hidden directly behind you, so, if you can't see all around your vehicle, get out and have a look. You could also ask someone reliable outside the vehicle to guide you.

question: What should you do when you park at night on a road that has a 40 mph speed limit?

explanation.text: You must use parking lights when parking at night on a road or in a lay-by on a road with a speed limit greater than 30 mph. You must also park in the direction of the traffic flow and not close to a junction.

question: Who has priority at an unmarked crossroads?

explanation.text: Practise good observation in all directions before you emerge or make a turn. Proceed only when you're sure it's safe to do so.

question: How far are you allowed to reverse?

options.option: No more than a car’s length
As far as it takes to reverse around a corner
The length of a residential street

explanation.text: You mustn't reverse further than is necessary. You may decide to turn your vehicle around by reversing into an opening or side road. When you reverse, always look all around you and watch for pedestrians. Don’t reverse from a side road into a main road.

question: What's the national speed limit for cars and motorcycles on a dual carriageway?

explanation.text: Make sure that you know the speed limit for the road that you're on. The speed limit on a dual carriageway or motorway is 70 mph for cars and motorcycles, unless signs indicate otherwise. The speed limits for different types of vehicle are listed in The Highway Code.

question: You're driving at night with your headlights on main beam. A vehicle is overtaking you. When should you dip your headlights?

options.option: Some time after the vehicle has passed you
Before the vehicle starts to pass you
Only if the other driver dips their headlights
As soon as the vehicle passes you

correct_answer: As soon as the vehicle passes you

explanation.text: On main beam, your lights could dazzle the driver in front. Dip your headlights as soon as the driver passes you and drop back so that the dipped beam falls short of the vehicle in front.

question: What should you do if you see a pedestrian waiting at a zebra crossing?

options.option: Go on quickly before they step onto the crossing
Stop before you reach the zigzag lines and let them cross
Be ready to slow down or stop to let them cross
Ignore them as they're still on the pavement

correct_answer: Be ready to slow down or stop to let them cross

explanation.text: By standing on the pavement, the pedestrian is showing an intention to cross. By looking well ahead, you'll give yourself time to see the pedestrian, check your mirrors and respond safely.

question: There are no speed-limit signs on the road. In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland how is a 30 mph limit generally indicated?

options.option: By double or single yellow lines

explanation.text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, there's a 30 mph speed limit where there are street lights unless signs show another limit.
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

question: You're on a road that's only wide enough for one vehicle. What should you do if a car is coming towards you?

options.option: Pull into a passing place on your right
Force the other driver to reverse
Pull into a passing place if your vehicle is wider
Pull into a passing place on your left

correct_answer: Pull into a passing place on your left

explanation.text: Pull into the nearest passing place on the left if you meet another vehicle on a narrow road. If the nearest passing place is on the right, wait opposite it.

question: Where may you overtake on a one-way street?

options.option: On either the right or the left

correct_answer: On either the right or the left

explanation.text: You can overtake other traffic on either side when travelling in a one-way street. Make full use of your mirrors and ensure it's clear all around before you attempt to overtake. Look for signs and road markings, and use the most suitable lane for your destination.

question: You're travelling on a motorway in England. When must you stop your vehicle?

options.option: When signalled to stop by a roadworks supervisor
When signalled to stop by a traffic officer
When signalled to stop by a pedestrian on the hard shoulder
When signalled to stop by a driver who has broken down

correct_answer: When signalled to stop by a traffic officer

explanation.text: You'll find traffic officers on motorways and some primary routes in England and Wales. They work in partnership with the police, helping to keep traffic moving and helping to make your journey as safe as possible. It's an offence not to comply with the directions given by a traffic officer.

question: How can driving in a fuel-efficient manner help protect the environment?

options.option: Through the legal enforcement of speed regulations
By increasing the number of cars on the road

explanation.text: Fuel-efficient driving is all about looking and planning further ahead. This helps raise your hazard awareness and reduces the need for late and heavy braking. This will make your journeys more comfortable, as well as considerably reducing your fuel bills and reducing emissions that can damage the environment.

question: What will reduce fuel consumption?

explanation.text:
Harsh braking, frequent gear changes and harsh acceleration increase fuel consumption. A car uses less fuel when travelling at a constant low speed in an appropriate high gear.
You need to look well ahead so you’re able to anticipate hazards early. Easing off the accelerator and timing your approach at junctions, for example, can reduce the fuel consumption of your vehicle.

question: How should you drive when you're driving along a road that has road humps?

options.option: Always keep to the maximum legal speed
Drive slowly at school times only

explanation.text: Road humps are there for a reason – to protect vulnerable road users by reducing the speed of traffic. Don’t accelerate harshly between the humps. Put the safety of others first and maintain a reduced speed throughout the zone.

question: When should you check the engine oil level?

options.option: Every time you drive the car

explanation.text:
An engine can use more oil during long journeys than on shorter trips. Insufficient engine oil is potentially dangerous: it can lead to excessive wear, mechanical breakdown and expensive repairs.
Most cars have a dipstick to allow the oil level to be checked. If not, you should refer to the vehicle handbook.

question: What's likely to happen if you put too much oil in your engine?

options.option: The air intake will become blocked

explanation.text: Too much oil will lead to increased pressure in the engine. This could damage oil seals and lead to oil leaks. Any excess oil should be drained off.

question: How much more fuel will you use by driving at 70 mph, compared with driving at 50 mph?

explanation.text: Your vehicle will use less fuel if you avoid heavy acceleration. The higher the engine revs, the more fuel you'll use. Using the same gear, and covering the same distance, a vehicle travelling at 70 mph will use about 15% more fuel than it would at 50 mph. However, don’t travel so slowly that you inconvenience or endanger other road users.

question: How will your journey be affected by travelling outside the busy times of day?

options.option: Your journey will use more fuel
Your journey will be more hazardous
Your journey will have fewer delays

correct_answer: Your journey will have fewer delays

explanation.text: If possible, avoid the early morning, late afternoon and early evening ‘rush hour’. Doing this should allow you to have a better journey, with fewer delays. This should help you to arrive at your destination feeling less stressed.

question: When is fuel consumption at its highest?

explanation.text: Accelerating uses a lot of fuel, so always try to use the accelerator smoothly. Taking your foot off the accelerator allows the momentum of the car to take you forward, especially when going downhill. This can save a considerable amount of fuel without any loss of control over the vehicle.

question: You're having difficulty finding a parking space in a busy town. Can you park on the zigzag lines of a zebra crossing?

options.option: No, not unless you stay with your car
Yes, in order to drop off a passenger
Yes, if you don't block people from crossing

explanation.text: It’s an offence to park on the zigzag lines of a zebra crossing. You'll be causing an obstruction by obscuring the view of both pedestrians and drivers.

question: When may a passenger travel in a car without wearing a seat belt?

options.option: When they're under 1.5 metres (5 feet) in height
When they're sitting in the rear seat
When they're exempt for medical reasons

correct_answer: When they're exempt for medical reasons

explanation.text: If you have adult passengers, it's their responsibility to wear a seat belt, but you should still remind them to use one as they get in the car. It's your responsibility to make sure that all children in your car are secured with an appropriate restraint. Exemptions are allowed for those with a medical exemption certificate.

question: What's the purpose of a catalytic converter?

options.option: To reduce the risk of fire

explanation.text: Catalytic converters reduce a large percentage of harmful exhaust emissions. They work more efficiently when the engine has reached its normal working temperature.

question: You're leaving your vehicle parked on a road and unattended. When may you leave the engine running?

options.option: If you'll be parking for less than five minutes
If the battery keeps going flat
When parked in a 20 mph zone
Never if you're away from the vehicle

correct_answer: Never if you're away from the vehicle

explanation.text: When you leave your vehicle parked on a road, switch off the engine and secure the vehicle. Make sure no valuables are visible, shut all the windows, lock the vehicle, and set the alarm if the vehicle has one.

question: You're driving a friend's children home from school. They're both under 14 years old. Who's responsible for making sure they wear a seat belt or approved child restraint where required?

explanation.text: Passengers should always be secured and safe. Children should be encouraged to fasten their seat belts or approved restraints themselves from an early age, so that it becomes a matter of routine. As the driver, you must check that they're fastened securely. It's your responsibility.

question: How can you reduce the chances of your car being broken into when leaving it unattended?

options.option: Place any valuables on the floor

explanation.text: When leaving your car, take all valuables with you if you can. Otherwise, lock them out of sight.

question: How can you reduce the risk of your vehicle being broken into at night?

options.option: Leave it in a well-lit area
Park in a quiet side road
Park in a poorly lit area

correct_answer: Leave it in a well-lit area

explanation.text: Having your vehicle broken into or stolen can be very distressing and inconvenient. Avoid leaving your vehicle unattended in poorly lit areas.

question: Why should you try and park in a secure car park?

options.option: It makes it easy to find your car
It stops the car being exposed to bad weather
It doesn't cost anything to park here

explanation.text: Whenever possible, leave your car in a secure car park. This will help deter thieves.

question: What should you do if your vehicle pulls to one side when you use the brakes?

options.option: Increase the pressure in your tyres
Have the brakes checked as soon as possible
Change gear and pump the brake pedal
Use your parking brake at the same time

correct_answer: Have the brakes checked as soon as possible

explanation.text: The brakes on your vehicle must be effective and properly adjusted. If your vehicle pulls to one side when braking, take it to be checked by a qualified mechanic as soon as you can.

question: How should you dispose of a used vehicle battery?

options.option: Take it to a local-authority disposal site

correct_answer: Take it to a local-authority disposal site

explanation.text: Batteries contain acid, which is hazardous, and they must be disposed of safely. This means taking them to an appropriate disposal site.

question: What could you do to reduce the volume of traffic on the roads?

options.option: Use a car with a smaller engine
Walk or cycle on short journeys
Travel by car at all times

correct_answer: Walk or cycle on short journeys

explanation.text: Try not to use your car as a matter of routine. For shorter journeys, consider walking or cycling instead - this is much better for both you and the environment.

question: What should you do when leaving your vehicle parked and unattended?

options.option: Lock it and remove the key

correct_answer: Lock it and remove the key

explanation.text: An unlocked car is an open invitation to thieves. Leaving the keys in the ignition not only makes your car easy to steal but could also invalidate your insurance.

question: You service your own vehicle. How should you dispose of the old engine oil?

options.option: Take it to a local-authority site
Tip it into a hole in the ground

correct_answer: Take it to a local-authority site

explanation.text: It's illegal to pour engine oil down any drain. Oil is a pollutant and harmful to wildlife. Dispose of it safely at an authorised site.

question: You're carrying two 13-year-old children and their parents in your car. Who's responsible for seeing that the children wear seat belts?

explanation.text: Seat belts save lives and reduce the risk of injury. If you're carrying passengers under 14 years old, it's your responsibility as the driver to ensure that their seat belts are fastened or they're seated in an approved child restraint.

question: The fluid level in your battery is low. What fluid should you use to top it up?

explanation.text: Some modern batteries are maintenance free. Check your vehicle handbook and, if necessary, make sure that the plates in each battery cell are covered with fluid.

question: What will help you to keep your car secure?

options.option: Being a member of a vehicle breakdown organisation
Registering with a Vehicle Watch scheme

correct_answer: Registering with a Vehicle Watch scheme

explanation.text: The Vehicle Watch scheme helps to reduce the risk of your car being stolen. By displaying high-visibility Vehicle Watch stickers in your car, you're inviting the police to stop your vehicle if it's seen in use between midnight and 5 am.

question: What does fuel-efficient driving achieve?

explanation.text: The emphasis is on hazard awareness and planning ahead. By looking well ahead, you'll have plenty of time to deal with hazards safely and won’t need to brake sharply. This will also reduce damage to the environment.

question: You're carrying an 11-year-old child on the front seat of your car. They're under 1.35 metres (4 feet 5 inches) tall. What seat belt security must be in place?

options.option: They must use an adult seat belt
They must be able to fasten their own seat belt
They must use a suitable child restraint
They must be able to see clearly out of the front window

correct_answer: They must use a suitable child restraint

explanation.text: As the driver, it's your responsibility to make sure that children are secure and safe in your vehicle. Make yourself familiar with the rules. When children are carried on the back seat, there are a few very exceptional cases when an adult seat belt can be used instead of a correct child restraint.

question: What does it mean if this light comes on while you're driving?

options.option: A fault in the braking system

correct_answer: A fault in the braking system

explanation.text: If this light comes on, you should have the brake system checked immediately. A faulty braking system could have dangerous consequences.

question: What's most likely to waste fuel?

explanation.text: Wasting fuel costs you money and also causes unnecessary pollution. Ensuring your tyres are correctly inflated, avoiding carrying unnecessary weight and removing a roof rack that's not in use will all help to reduce your fuel consumption.

question: What's most likely to increase fuel consumption?

explanation.text: Accelerating and braking gently and smoothly will help to save fuel and reduce wear on your vehicle. This makes it better for the environment too.

question: What's the most important reason for having a properly adjusted head restraint?

options.option: To help you avoid neck injury
To help you maintain your driving position

correct_answer: To help you avoid neck injury

explanation.text: In a collision, rapid deceleration will violently throw vehicle occupants forward and then backwards as the vehicle stops. Seat belts and airbags protect occupants against the forward movement. Head restraints should be adjusted so they give maximum protection to the head and neck during the backward movement.

question: You need to top up your battery with distilled water. What level should you fill it to?

explanation.text: Top up the battery with distilled water and make sure each cell plate is covered.

question: What should you do if your anti-lock brakes (ABS) warning light stays on?

options.option: Check that the parking brake is released

explanation.text: Consult the vehicle handbook or a garage before driving the vehicle any further. Only drive to a garage if it's safe to do so. If you aren't sure, get expert help.

question: On a vehicle, where would you find a catalytic converter?

explanation.text: Although carbon dioxide is still produced, a catalytic converter fitted to the exhaust system reduces the toxic and polluting gases by up to 90%.

question: You want to put a rear-facing baby seat on the front passenger seat. What must you do if the passenger seat is protected by a frontal airbag?

options.option: Turn the seat to face sideways
Ask a passenger to hold the baby
Put the child in an adult seat belt

explanation.text: It's illegal to fit a rear-facing baby seat into a passenger seat protected by an active frontal airbag. If the airbag activates, it could cause serious injury or even death to the child. You must secure it in a different seat or deactivate the relevant airbag. Follow the manufacturer's advice when fitting a baby seat.

question: What can cause excessive or uneven tyre wear?

explanation.text: If you see that parts of the tread on your tyres are wearing before others, it may indicate a brake, suspension or wheel-alignment fault. Regular servicing will help to detect faults at an early stage and this will avoid the risk of minor faults becoming serious or even dangerous.

question: How will you benefit from following the manufacturer's service schedule for your vehicle?

options.option: Your vehicle will be cheaper to insure
Your vehicle tax will be lower
Your journey times will be reduced

explanation.text: All vehicles need to be serviced to keep working efficiently. An efficient engine uses less fuel and produces fewer harmful emissions than an engine that's running inefficiently. Keeping the vehicle serviced to the manufacturer's schedule should also keep it reliable and reduce the chance of it breaking down.

question: When will your vehicle use more fuel?

options.option: When its tyres are of different makes

explanation.text: Check your tyre pressures frequently - normally once a week. If they're lower than those recommended by the manufacturer, there will be more 'rolling resistance'. The engine will have to work harder to overcome this, leading to increased fuel consumption.

question: What can you do to reduce environmental damage caused by your vehicle?

options.option: Use the air conditioning whenever you drive
Use the gears to slow the vehicle
Avoid making a lot of short journeys

correct_answer: Avoid making a lot of short journeys

explanation.text: Avoid using your car for short journeys. On a short journey, the engine is unlikely to warm up fully and will therefore be running less efficiently. This will result in the car using more fuel and emitting higher levels of harmful emissions.

question: How can you reduce the environmental harm caused by your motor vehicle?

options.option: Only use it for short journeys

explanation.text: Engines that burn fossil fuels produce exhaust emissions that are harmful to health. The harder you make the engine work, the more emissions it will produce. Engines also use more fuel and produce higher levels of emissions when they're cold. Anything you can do to reduce your use of fossil fuels will help the environment.

question: Why do MOT tests include an exhaust emission test?

options.option: To recover the cost of expensive garage equipment
To help protect the environment against pollution
To discover which fuel supplier is used the most
To make sure diesel and petrol engines emit the same fumes

correct_answer: To help protect the environment against pollution

explanation.text: Emission tests are carried out to make sure your vehicle’s engine is operating efficiently. This ensures the pollution produced by the engine is kept to a minimum. If your vehicle isn't serviced regularly, it may fail the MOT emissions test.

question: What does it mean if your vehicle keeps bouncing after you sharply press down and release on the bodywork over a wheel?

options.option: The vehicle is on soft ground

explanation.text: If you find that your vehicle bounces as you drive around a corner or bend in the road, the shock absorbers might be worn. To test your shock absorbers, sharply press down and release above each wheel. If the vehicle continues to bounce, take it to be checked by a qualified mechanic.

question: How would under-inflated tyres affect your vehicle?

options.option: The vehicle's stopping distance would increase
The flash rate of the vehicle's indicators would increase
The vehicle's gear change mechanism would become stiff
The vehicle's headlights would aim high

correct_answer: The vehicle's stopping distance would increase

explanation.text: Your tyres are your only contact with the road. To prevent problems with braking and steering, keep your tyres free from defects; they must have sufficient tread depth and be correctly inflated. Correct tyre pressures help reduce the risk of skidding and provide a safer and more comfortable drive or ride.

question: When are you not allowed to sound your vehicle's horn?

options.option: Between 10.00 pm and 6.00 am in a built-up area
At any time in a built-up area
Between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am in a built-up area
Between 11.30 pm and 6.00 am on any road

correct_answer: Between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am in a built-up area

explanation.text: Every effort must be made to prevent excessive noise, especially in built-up areas at night. Don’t rev your engine or sound the horn unnecessarily. It's illegal to sound your horn in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am, except when another road user poses a danger.

question: How will a roof rack affect your car?

options.option: There will be less wind noise
The engine will use more oil

explanation.text: A roof rack increases your car's wind resistance. This will cause an increase in fuel consumption, so you should remove it when it isn't being used. An aerodynamically designed roof rack or box will help reduce wind resistance to a minimum, but the rack or box should still be removed when it isn't in use.

question: What may help to deter a thief from stealing your car?

options.option: Always keeping the interior light on
Etching the registration number on the windows

correct_answer: Etching the registration number on the windows

explanation.text: Having your car registration number etched on all your windows is a cheap and effective way to deter professional car thieves.

question: What will happen if your car's wheels are unbalanced?

options.option: The steering will pull to one side

explanation.text: If your wheels are out of balance, it will cause the steering to vibrate at certain speeds. This isn't a fault that will put itself right, so take your vehicle to a garage or tyre fitter to have the wheels rebalanced.

question: You plan your route before starting a journey. Why should you also plan an alternative route?

options.option: Your original route may be blocked
Your maps may have different scales
You may find you have to pay a congestion charge
You may get held up by a tractor

correct_answer: Your original route may be blocked

explanation.text: It can be frustrating and worrying to find your planned route is blocked by roadworks or diversions. If you've planned an alternative, you'll feel less stressed and more able to concentrate fully on your driving or riding. If your original route is mostly on motorways, it’s a good idea to plan an alternative using non-motorway roads. Always carry a map with you just in case you need to refer to it.

question: You're parked on the road at night. When must you use parking lights?

options.option: When there are continuous white lines in the middle of the road
When the speed limit exceeds 30 mph
When you're near a bus stop

correct_answer: When the speed limit exceeds 30 mph

explanation.text: When parking at night, park in the direction of the traffic. This will enable other road users to see the reflectors on the rear of your vehicle. Use your parking lights if the speed limit is over 30 mph.

question: How can you help to prevent your car radio being stolen?
