The rider may be travelling faster than normal

correct_answer: The rider may be blown in front of you

explanation.text: If you’re driving in high winds, be aware that the conditions might make a motorcyclist (or cyclist) swerve or wobble. Take this into consideration if you’re following or wish to overtake a two-wheeled vehicle.

question: You're turning left from a main road into a side road. What should you do if there's a pedestrian on the pavement waiting to cross the side road?

options.option: Flash your lights to encourage the pedestrian to cross
Carry on turning into the side road
Sound your horn to let the pedestrian know you're there
Wait and give way to the pedestrian

correct_answer: Wait and give way to the pedestrian

explanation.text: You should give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross the road into which or from which you're turning. Be patient if they're cautious, and let them check that it's safe from all directions before they step into the road. Do not signal or wave them to cross.

question: You're following a cyclist. What should you do when you wish to turn left a short distance ahead?

options.option: Overtake the cyclist before you reach the junction
Pull alongside the cyclist and stay level until after the junction
Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction
Go around the cyclist on the junction

correct_answer: Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction

explanation.text: Make allowances for cyclists, and give them plenty of room. Don’t overtake and then immediately turn left. Be patient and turn behind them when they've passed the junction.

question: Which sign means that there may be people walking along the road?

explanation.text: Always check the road signs. Triangular signs are warning signs: they inform you about hazards ahead and help you to anticipate any problems. There are a number of different signs showing pedestrians. Learn the meaning of each one.

question: Why should you look carefully for motorcyclists and cyclists at junctions?

options.option: They may want to turn into the side road
They may slow down to let you turn
They might not see you turn

explanation.text: Cyclists and motorcyclists are smaller than other vehicles and so are more difficult to see. They can easily be hidden from your view by cars parked near a junction.

question: You're approaching a roundabout. What should you do if there are horses being ridden in front of you?

options.option: Sound your horn as a warning
Treat them like any other vehicle
Accelerate past as quickly as possible

explanation.text: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

question: Which vehicle should you allow extra room as you overtake them?

explanation.text:
Don’t pass cyclists too closely, as they may
  • need to veer around a pothole, drain or other hazard
  • be buffeted by side wind
  • be made unsteady by your vehicle.
Always leave as much room as you would for a car, and don’t cut in front of them.

question: Why do motorcyclists wear bright clothing?

options.option: They must do so by law
It helps keep them cool in summer

explanation.text: Motorcycles and scooters are generally smaller than other vehicles and can be difficult to see. Wearing bright clothing makes it easier for other road users to see a motorcyclist approaching, especially at junctions.

question: This junction, controlled by traffic lights, has a marked area between two stop lines. What's this for?

options.option: To allow taxis to position in front of other traffic
To allow people with disabilities to cross the road
To allow cyclists and pedestrians to cross the road together
To allow cyclists to position in front of other traffic

correct_answer: To allow cyclists to position in front of other traffic

explanation.text: These are known as advanced stop lines. When the lights are red (or about to become red), you should stop at the first white line. However, if you've crossed that line as the lights change, you must stop at the second line even if it means you're in the area reserved for cyclists.

question: What should you do when you're following a learner driver who stalls at a junction?

options.option: Be patient, as you expect them to make mistakes
Stay very close behind and flash your headlights
Start to rev your engine if they take too long to restart
Immediately steer around them and drive on

correct_answer: Be patient, as you expect them to make mistakes

explanation.text: Learning to drive is a process of practice and experience. Try to understand this and tolerate those who make mistakes while they're learning.

question: You're approaching a roundabout. What should you do if a cyclist ahead is signalling to turn right?

options.option: Give a warning with your horn
Signal the cyclist to move across
Give the cyclist plenty of room

correct_answer: Give the cyclist plenty of room

explanation.text: If you’re following a cyclist who’s signalling to turn right at a roundabout, leave plenty of room. Give them space and time to get into the correct lane.

question: What would you do if you see older people crossing the road ahead?

options.option: Wave them across so they know that you've seen them
Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time
Rev the engine to let them know that you're waiting
Tap the horn in case they're hard of hearing

correct_answer: Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time

explanation.text: Be aware that older people might take a long time to cross the road. They might also be hard of hearing and not hear you approaching. Don't hurry older people across the road by getting too close to them or revving your engine.

question: You're approaching this roundabout. What should you do when a cyclist is keeping to the left while signalling to turn right?

explanation.text: Cycling in today’s heavy traffic can be hazardous. Some cyclists may not feel safe crossing the path of traffic to take up a position in an outside lane. Be aware of this and understand that, although they're in the left-hand lane, the cyclist might be turning right.

question: A horse rider is in the left-hand lane approaching a roundabout. Where should you expect the rider to go?

explanation.text: Horses and their riders move more slowly than other road users. They might not have time to cut across heavy traffic to take up a position in the right-hand lane. For this reason, a horse and rider may approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane even though they're turning right.

question: You're waiting to come out of a side road. Why should you look carefully for motorcycles?

options.option: Motorcycles are usually faster than cars
Motorcycles can easily be hidden behind obstructions

correct_answer: Motorcycles can easily be hidden behind obstructions

explanation.text: If you're waiting to emerge from a side road, look carefully for motorcycles: they can be difficult to see. Be especially careful if there are parked vehicles or other obstructions restricting your view.

question: You want to turn right from a junction. What should you do if your view is restricted by parked vehicles?

options.option: Move out quickly, but be prepared to stop
Sound your horn and pull out if there's no reply
Stop, then move forward slowly until you have a clear view
Stop, get out and look along the main road to check

correct_answer: Stop, then move forward slowly until you have a clear view

explanation.text:
If you want to turn right from a junction and your view is restricted, stop. Ease forward until you can see – something might be approaching.
If you don't know, don't go.

question: What should you do when you're passing loose sheep on the road?

options.option: Herd them to the side of the road

explanation.text: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if you're signalled to do so by the person in charge.

question: Where should you take particular care to look for motorcyclists and cyclists?

explanation.text: Motorcyclists and cyclists are often more difficult to see at junctions. They're easily hidden from view and you may not be able to see them approaching a junction if your view is partially blocked; for example, by other traffic.

question: What should you do if the left-hand pavement is closed due to street repairs?

options.option: Watch out for pedestrians walking in the road
Use your right-hand mirror more often
Speed up to get past the roadworks more quickly
Position close to the left-hand kerb

correct_answer: Watch out for pedestrians walking in the road

explanation.text: Where street repairs have closed off pavements, proceed carefully and slowly, as pedestrians might have to walk in the road.

question: You're driving past a line of parked cars. What should you do if a ball bounces out into the road ahead?

options.option: Continue driving at the same speed and sound your horn
Continue driving at the same speed and flash your headlights
Slow down and be prepared to stop for children
Stop and wave the children across to fetch their ball

correct_answer: Slow down and be prepared to stop for children

explanation.text: Beware of children playing in the street and running out into the road. If a ball bounces out from the pavement, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don’t encourage anyone to retrieve it. Other road users may not see your signal and you might lead a child into a dangerous situation.

question: You're about to reverse into a side road. What should you do if a pedestrian is waiting to cross behind your car?

options.option: Wave to the pedestrian to stop
Sound your horn to warn the pedestrian
Reverse before the pedestrian starts to cross

explanation.text: If you need to reverse into a side road, try to find a place that’s free from traffic and pedestrians. Look all around before and during the manoeuvre. Stop and give way to any pedestrians who want to cross behind you. Avoid waving them across, sounding the horn, flashing your lights or giving any signals that could mislead them and create a dangerous situation.

question: You're about to overtake a cyclist on a road that has a 30 mph speed limit. How much room should you leave them as you overtake?

options.option: At least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car

correct_answer: At least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car

explanation.text: You should leave cyclists at least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car. Leave them more room if you're overtaking at speeds over 30 mph.
